The most jarring example is Shem Tob's copy of the gospel of Matthew in Hebrew. What's bizarre is that it often agrees with *Luke* over Matthew when using the Q source. Interesting, because often the Lukan version is more primitive and Hebraic than the Matthean version. I don't just mean minor details either. For example, the part where the people ask John what to do in chapter 3 is not extant in canonical Matthew, but it *is* in Luke...and a shorter version is also found in Hebrew Matthew! My guess is that Q was originally written in Hebrew, and that Shem Tob's text made use of this or padded it out with translations of the parts of Mark that were incorporated. And Matthew and Luke both made use of some sort of Greek translation of this document. More evidence is that the Shem Tob version also has several agreements with the gospel of Thomas over the canonical gospels, which also utilized Q. As well as agreements with long lost manuscripts not available in his time, so these variants could not have been the results of tampering by Jewish scribes (which did happen, as it also did to the canonical version by Roman scribes).

Some of these old manuscripts also appear to be checked against older sources, including Q, and often the original Hebrew version too. Sinaiticus and Bezae in particular have several variants in the synoptic gospels and even Acts which come from older versions than are available to us today, and updates from source documents that were originally erroneously copied. Some manuscripts of the Old Latin and Old Syriac have similar variants.

The gospel of the Hebrews, too, looks like it made use of this document, or an extremely early version of Luke. I cannot say it *is* Q, as it's definitely edited and harmonized from the existing gospels, but in places it gives a more primitive reading. Such as the beginning: "And it was in the days of Herod king of Judea, during the priesthood of Caiapha, a man named John went..." which is shorter and noticeably more Hebraic than Luke 3:1, and also has an incorrect detail about Herod being king of Judea instead of Galilee (and it's very hard to imagine a redactor editing it to make it shorter and more incorrect).

It may be that the story of the woman caught in adultery is also part of Q, as its style is very Lukan and it appears in a number of early manuscripts in the gospel of Luke instead of John. Perhaps scribes noticed it was not included in any of the canonical gospels and were trying to find a good place to put it before abandoning Q and losing it.

Is greed relative or absolute? If it is absolute, would you consider most people in "first world" countries to be greedy? Is living a more "primitive" life important in order to not be greedy?

There's an economic concept of absolute vs. relative poverty:

> Absolute poverty is the lack of one or more basic needs over a period long enough that it endangers your life or can cause it harm. As opposed to relative poverty, it covers vital and biological needs such as food, water, clothing, basic housing (or anything that looks like a decent roof over your head), and a minimum of sanitation.

https://www.poverties.org/blog/relative-vs-absolute-poverty

Where do you draw the line on what is and isn't greedy today?

[Catholic Encyclopedia on greed (avarice):](https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02148b.htm)

> Avarice (from Latin avarus, "greedy"; "to crave") is the inordinate love for riches. Its special malice, broadly speaking, lies in that it makes the getting and keeping of money, possessions, and the like, a purpose in itself to live for. It does not see that these things are valuable only as instruments for the conduct of a rational and harmonious life, due regard being paid of course to the special social condition in which one is placed. It is called a capital vice because it has as its object that for the gaining or holding of which many other sins are committed. It is more to be dreaded in that it often cloaks itself as a virtue, or insinuates itself under the pretext of making a decent provision for the future. In so far as avarice is an incentive to injustice in acquiring and retaining of wealth, it is frequently a grievous sin. In itself, however, and in so far as it implies simply an excessive desire of, or pleasure in, riches, it is commonly not a mortal sin.

[Aquinas On Greed](https://www.newadvent.org/summa/3118.htm)

Some of these old manuscripts also appear to be checked against older sources, including Q, and often the original Hebrew version too. Sinaiticus and Bezae in particular have several variants in the synoptic gospels and even Acts which come from older versions than are available to us today, and updates from source documents that were originally erroneously copied. Some manuscripts of the Old Latin and Old Syriac have similar variants.

The gospel of the Hebrews, too, looks like it made use of this document, or an extremely early version of Luke. I cannot say it is Q, as it's definitely edited and harmonized from the existing gospels, but in places it gives a more primitive reading. Such as the beginning: "And it was in the days of Herod king of Judea, during the priesthood of Caiapha, a man named John went..." which is shorter and noticeably more Hebraic than Luke 3:1, and also has an incorrect detail about Herod being king of Judea instead of Galilee (and it's very hard to imagine a redactor editing it to make it shorter and more incorrect).

While I've expressed some concern about rock music and probably think Christians should avoid it, on this topic some of the lyrics of the rock band "Black Sabbath" come to mind (from their song ["War Pigs"](https://www.metrolyrics.com/war-pigs-lyrics-black-sabbath.html)):

> Time will tell on their power minds
> Making war just for fun
> Treating people just like pawns in chess
> Wait 'til their judgement day comes

> Now in darkness world stops turning
> Ashes where the bodies burning
> No more war pigs have the power
> Hand of God has struck the hour
> Day of judgement, God is calling
> On their knees the war pig's crawling
> Begging mercy for their sins
> Satan laughing spreads his wings

This sounds kind of like a rock adaptation, consciously or unconsciously of the older traditional ["Dies Irae" song:](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dies_irae) 

> Oh, what fear man's bosom rendeth,
> When from heaven the Judge descendeth,
> On whose sentence all dependeth.

Culturally, it seems like there was an awareness in the past that politicians (for example) who are in power and abuse their power (and commit sin) would be judged for doing so on Judgment Day. Reminding them that God is all-powerful and that there is no appeal against the verdict decided on Judgment Day, can act as a powerful psychological tool to correct abuses in the world. 

If more politicians were reminded that God can punish them also in this world and even cut their lives short in this life, or could cast them in to hell for ever in the next life, perhaps they would repent or turn away from the sins they commit (even out of a simple fear for self-preservation, if they had not developed a love of doing what is good). 

> There is a way which seemeth just to a man: but the ends thereof lead to death. Proverbs 14:12

We saw how that [Argentinian pro-abortion leader](https://www.liveaction.org/news/leader-argentina-dies-legally-taking-abortion-drug/) tragically died while having an abortion. She thought she was safe, but was not; God allowed her to be delivered over to sin, and then the sin brought about her death. And it is fearful to think of what God's judgment will be over her soul.

So, spreading this reminder of the fear of God's judgment might help to correct politicians, or to inspire us to reform our own lives which is important for improving our world.

> Thou hypocrite, cast out first the beam in thy own eye, and then shalt thou see to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye. Matthew 7:5

Just as Jordan Peterson encourages people to "clean their room" (or work to improve the problems in their own lives) before expecting to see the world reformed, we might look at the things that need improvement in our own lives before expecting to see some kind of political change out in the world. 

And for politicians or ourselves, if we are willing to be sorry from the heart and willing to actually change for the better and to try to make up for bad things we have done, the Bible speaks in multiple verses about God's willingness to forgive.

> If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just, to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all iniquity. 1 John 1:9

What do you think we could do to spread this awareness of the coming of Judgment Day, or what else on these topics should we talk about?

Addendum: typo fixed, "pro-life" to "pro-abortion"

That some sketchy denominations believe in these doesn't make them guilty by association. The closest thing to hell among early Christians was some universalists believing in a temporary purgatory-like place of punishment, and more similar to underworld myths than a place where people burn 24/7. Even if hell was mentioned, there is even less indication of an "end of grace" that everyone seems to think is going to happen, as if Jesus's sacrifice wasn't good enough. Actually the gospels mention Jesus evangelizing to the dead before his resurrection, which would be pointless if it was too late for them. And don't start telling me about Tribulation, because the whole point of that is to try and convince people to change their minds.

> I have no idea about original greek, but there are numerous places where hell is described in parables by Jesus.

See that's kinda the problem, the translations are in many places dishonest and swayed by the beliefs of the translators. When you see "hell" in your bible, know that it's actually either the grave, Hades, or Gehenna. Only the devil is said to be tortured "forever" in the "lake of fire" and the authenticity of Revelation is itself questionable.

The grave: Figurative place where dead people are, or the state of being dead, and in the old testament everyone goes there. You probably already know. It's pretty safe to rule this out.

Hades: Greek place of the dead, used to translate the former term. Usually it is used for the same purpose, not as much for the Greek concept of it with the underworld.

Gehenna: Hell is right here on Earth, apparently. This is a valley where the Pharisees burned people who they ostracized as "sinners". It was regarded as cursed for that reason. The new testament sometimes alludes to it as either a place of death and complete destruction or a tragic fate of not being allowed to enter the kingdom, depending on the interpretation. Not where God mercilessly burns people forever.

> Making war just for fun

> No more war pigs have the power
> Hand of God has struck the hour
> Day of judgement, God is calling
> On their knees the war pig's crawling
> Begging mercy for their sins
> Satan laughing spreads his wings

This sounds kind of like a rock adaptation, consciously or unconsciously of the older traditional ["Dies Irae" song:](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dies_irae) 

> Oh, what fear man's bosom rendeth,
> When from heaven the Judge descendeth,
> On whose sentence all dependeth.

Culturally, it seems like there was an awareness in the past that politicians (for example) who are in power and abuse their power (and commit sin) would be judged for doing so on Judgment Day. Reminding them that God is all-powerful and that there is no appeal against the verdict decided on Judgment Day, can act as a powerful psychological tool to correct abuses in the world. 

If more politicians were reminded that God can punish them also in this world and even cut their lives short in this life, or could cast them in to hell for ever in the next life, perhaps they would repent or turn away from the sins they commit (even out of a simple fear for self-preservation, if they had not developed a love of doing what is good). 

> There is a way which seemeth just to a man: but the ends thereof lead to death. Proverbs 14:12

We saw how that [Argentinian pro-abortion leader](https://www.liveaction.org/news/leader-argentina-dies-legally-taking-abortion-drug/) tragically died while having an abortion. She thought she was safe, but was not; God allowed her to be delivered over to sin, and then the sin brought about her death. And it is fearful to think of what God's judgment will be over her soul.

So, spreading this reminder of the fear of God's judgment might help to correct politicians, or to inspire us to reform our own lives which is important for improving our world.

> Thou hypocrite, cast out first the beam in thy own eye, and then shalt thou see to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye. Matthew 7:5

Just as Jordan Peterson encourages people to "clean their room" (or work to improve the problems in their own lives) before expecting to see the world reformed, we might look at the things that need improvement in our own lives before expecting to see some kind of political change out in the world. 

And for politicians or ourselves, if we are willing to be sorry from the heart and willing to actually change for the better and to try to make up for bad things we have done, the Bible speaks in multiple verses about God's willingness to forgive.

> If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just, to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all iniquity. 1 John 1:9

What do you think we could do to spread this awareness of the coming of Judgment Day, or what else on these topics should we talk about?

People see other stuff too. And it's almost never consistent. Most of it is just made up for money or attention, and the rest is *usually* a dream.

> I really don't like your approach to Bible and how you just scrap and throw away great parts of it.

Then the new testament probably isn't your book. It scraps HUGE parts of the old testament and flat out condemns them. Actually the prophets in the old testament did too, and the earliest ones weren't even aware of the books currently in our bibles, so I guess you can't believe them either. You're basically left with Samaritanism. But the evidence points to the prophets and Jesus. Most of the bible is just stuff some guys wrote down and gave their opinions. The rest is still tampered with by scribes. And it's very interesting how the parts that were probably added by scribes are *exactly* the ones Jesus would have an issue with, centuries later.

> Hell is described many times, maybe not by this word, but by which people will be there and what will hapen there.

I didn't say that, I said there's a *chance* it is. The fact is it *was* disputed in the early days, and a few claims were even made that John saw it and condemned it. That doesn't mean they are true, it just means that it's a possibility, so it can't be trusted as absolute truth, and if the gospels appear to contradict it then they should take precedence. But if it is authentic it's most likely a prophecy about Nero (who is 666) and the destruction of Jerusalem in 70 AD.

Yeah, because fire is a metaphor for destruction and death, either literally or in the sense of not having anything to live for. I am not just pulling shit out of my ass, this is how it was interpreted by Christians in the first few centuries.

> > Then shall he answer them, saying, Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye did it not to one of the least of these, ye did it not to me. And these shall go away into everlasting punishment: but the righteous into life eternal.
>
